close_symbols: struct OS_queue_internal_record_t (definition, especially queue_name, max_depth, max_size)
system PID maximum (e.g. PID_MAX or kernel pid_max value / max decimal digits of getpid())
invariant/contract that queue_name is null-terminated (where/when it is written)
explanation:
For verifying MISRA rule on string functions in this function the analyzer must determine possible buffer/operand lengths and whether reads/writes can go out of bounds:

- OS_MAX_API_NAME
  - The local buffer 'name' is sized as OS_MAX_API_NAME * 2. The numeric value is required to compute the actual byte capacity of 'name' and check it against the formatted output length.

- struct OS_queue_internal_record_t (definition, especially queue_name, max_depth, max_size)
  - The code passes queue->queue_name to snprintf. The precise type and size of queue_name (e.g. whether it is an array and its maximum length) and whether it is guaranteed null-terminated are required to determine if %s can read past its bounds. max_depth/max_size are not directly relevant to string bounds but are part of the struct and present in the function.

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET (macro)
  - This macro yields the 'queue' pointer. To be confident that accessing queue->queue_name is valid (addressable and size as declared), the macro semantics and any indexing or bounds checks it performs must be known.

- OS_queue_table (declaration/type)
  - The object table symbol and its element type are needed together with OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET to ensure the returned pointer references a full OS_queue_internal_record_t object (so reading queue_name is valid).

- system PID maximum (e.g. PID_MAX or kernel pid_max value / max decimal digits of getpid())
  - The formatted string includes the process id as decimal. The worst-case number of decimal digits for getpid() must be known (or an upper bound) to compute the maximum required length of the formatted string and ensure 'name' cannot overflow.

- invariant/contract that queue_name is null-terminated (where/when it is written)
  - The danger with %s in snprintf is that it will read until a NUL byte; if queue_name is not guaranteed NUL-terminated, snprintf can read out-of-bounds of queue_name even if 'name' has sufficient space. The analyzer needs the rules or functions that write/populate queue_name (or an explicit invariant) proving it is always NUL-terminated within its declared size.

These symbols/definitions are sufficient to determine (1) the maximum number of bytes snprintf might write into 'name' and therefore whether name's bounds can be exceeded, and (2) whether snprintf can read beyond queue_name's storage when consuming the %s argument. Other symbols in the function (mq_open, memset, mq_attr, errno, strerror, mq_unlink, getpid prototype) do not affect string bounds reasoning beyond the items listed above.
